A subacute Brown-Séquard cervical myelopathy in a middle-aged woman is most suggestive of an intrinsic inflammatory/demyelinating lesion such as multiple sclerosis, but compressive pathology must be urgently excluded because it is time-critical. The recent respiratory illness and raised CRP widen the differential to include infectious and post-infectious myelitis, while vascular and granulomatous causes are less likely but important alternatives.
